{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3319193,"name":"Carl Hauser","username":"chauser","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/a587f6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-27T21:43:26.369Z","cooked":"

We are seeing visibly slower-than-expected acceleration with our Neos and Neo 550s on our shooter and this seems to be confirmed by data collected from wpilogs. Here is a graph of the behavior of one of the motors – in this case a Neo 550.

shooterSpinup1582×1033 149 KB

The motor output (obtained with motorController.getAppliedOutput()) is the bottom line and shows that value taking 0.3 seconds to go from 0 to 1. The current (obtained from the PDH in the DS log) is the red line; and the motor speed is the gray line (I have a hunch that the red line is about 0.04s to the right of where it should be due to slight misalignment of the two logs or delay between the current is read by the PDH and recorded in the DS log.)
The motor has a 20A current limit and is in Coast mode. The code does a motorController.setVoltage(11) at the point where the motor is turned on.

The other Neo 550 and two Neos are similarly configured and controlled, except the Neos are in Brake mode, and all show similar behavior – no sign that current limits are coming into play yet the applied output only slowly increases.

I think the big mystery here is why does it take the applied output so long to reach full value. The data do not show that the current limit is being hit during the time that the applied output is substantially less than what we expect. Do we have a fundamental misunderstanding of the how the current limits or setVoltage should work?

The NEO velocity measurement has a substantial default filter, because the NEO sensor is not very high-resolution. You’re seeing the phase lag from the filtering - in reality the motor is moving much faster than the plot shows.

See:

PSA: Default NEO/SparkMax velocity readings are still bad for flywheels Technical Discussion
I’ve been coaching 449 through some signal integrity issues with their flywheels, and in the process we generated a pretty telling plot re: the default velocity filtering settings on the NEO: [image] The blue value is a REV through-bore encoder wired to the RIO w/ 1x decoding and 127 samplesToAverage. The red is the reported velocity from the spark max. Notice the substantial signal degradation due to the aggressive smoothing used by the default …

I’ve read that discussion but I’m not convinced that is what we are seeing. The motor is visibly slow to accelerate and the applied output measurement is consistent with that.
